job_title: Residential Childcare Worker in Kirkcaldy, Scotland
pros: Frontline staff really want to do a good job by service users, despite continuous cuts and ridiculous red tape staff do their best with what they have for the children. Good reward scheme. Not all services with the organisation reflect this review. Without the dedication of the frontline staff teams the service would be on its knees to the true detriment of the service users.
cons: Uncompetitive wage structure, limited progression - unless to management, under qualified management team, limited training, failing reputation, decisions made by higher management micro managing case loads for children they have no knowledge or relationship with, staffing ratios rarely met placing children and staff at risk, no support or compassion for safety of ill or pregnant employees in high risk/volatile situations same for employees not trained in crisis limitation yet are expected to manage these situations - placing them at risk of being libel if something goes terrible wrong, services micro managed from afar impacting attempts to provide person centred care, promotions given to staff with little experience or knowledge to fill gaps from extremely high staff turnover in a ‘face fits’ culture, senior management preach success when the true picture shows a number of service users failed or moved on, feel good success stories are often used to advertise success when these situations are not the realistic outlook for the majority, limited attempts for senior management to understand the value of a secure staff team to provide an excellent level of service the children deserve, staff often work over and above their hours to provide a service - this is often unrecognised and unpaid, working well over and above regular working hours is often expected and not monitored, if this doesn’t suit staff are blamed for working the hours that cover was not provided for. The service operates firmly in a ‘blame culture’ and therefore nothing is ever resolved, top down bullying is an expected ‘norm’.  Senior management turn a blind eye to seriously volatile and violent situations unless these are questioned by other areas of the company such as HR or health and safety. Senior management carve out high paid job roles for themselves and justify these despite a lack of funds to pay for actual staff on the floor, this is then covered by unpaid management on a single on call payment.  Sleepover rates below national minimum wage.
